multiple-choice.question: Let $n \geq 7$ be an integer. Why does the following equality hold: $$ {n \choose 5}{n - 5 \choose 2} = {n \choose 2}{n - 2 \choose 5} $$
multiple-choice.answer: Because both sides count the number of pairs $(A,B)$ of subsets of the $n$ people, such that $|A| = 2$, $|B| = 5$, and $A \subseteq B$.
Because both sides count the number of pairs $(A,B)$ of subsets of the $n$ people, such that $|A| = 5$, $|B| = 2$, and $A \subseteq B$.
Because both sides count the number of ways to choose 2 committees in a group of $n$ people, one committee has 5 members, the other committee has 2 members, and a person can be on both committees.
Because both sides count the number of ways to choose 2 committees in a group of $n$ people, one committee has 5 members, the other committee has 2 members, and no person can be on both committees.
